reading_mnemonic: The reading is the reading you learned with the kanji. It's treated like a jukugo reading because it's normally attached to things.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. いち goes to いっ.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a combination of the on'yomi reading of 両 and the kun'yomi reading of 腕. You've learned them both, so you know this too!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help if you know the word 中国 already.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help if you know 主観.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. It shares its reading with the word 備える, which you learned a level ago, but in case you need a reminder, here it is:

What's the best way for your servants <vocabulary>to make an offering</vocabulary>? When they <vocabulary>offer</vocabulary> up their sauna (そな)! You really value a warm and relaxing sauna session at the end of the day.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You learned the kun'yomi reading for 値 in the vocabulary word 値(ね). You learned the reading for 札 in the vocabulary 札(ふだ). Put them together and you have ねふだ.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help if you know the word 大統領 first, though.
This word uses the on'yomi reading for 半 and the kun'yomi reading for 袖. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this word.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Also, it shares the reading with 営業.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know 営業 first as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The こく gets shortened to a nice little こっ.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: What <vocabulary>model</vocabulary> <reading>cutter</reading> (かた) is this? I can only use a certain <vocabulary>type</vocabulary> for my work.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: You walk up to the boundary. You're there to pick something up to take it across. This thing you're smuggling across the boundary is a <reading>sockeye</reading> (さかい) salmon. You take it across the boundary and sell it for a big profit.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

The readings for this one are the kun'yomi readings of each kanji. 子 is こ, like the individual vocab word. 供 is ども, however. Remember this by thinking how much <vocabulary>children</vocabulary> love <reading>domo</reading>-kun (ども).

Also, 子ども is kind of more "politically correct" with the kana hanging off there. 子供 is still used in a lot of situations, usually stiff ones. The second kanji means servant, and some people don't like that. The second version pops up a decent amount, so it's good to be familiar with that as well.
This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, but you know them both now, so you should be able to read this too!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It also just takes the reading from 寝坊.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just watch out for rendaku turning はん into ぱん (as is so often the case after ん).

This is a jukugo word, but it uses kun'yomi instead of on'yomi, so watch out for that!
The reading of the kanji is actually the same as the reading for this word, making things easy (both on'yomi and kun'yomi are さ).
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

The reading might look a little strange, but makes sense once you get it. You already know that the verb 建てる means "to build", and that a もの is a "thing". Now just remove the る part from the verb to make it a noun, combine it with もの, and we get <reading>たてもの</reading>! Just remember that it’s all kun’yomi since it comes from the verb 建てる.
The reading comes from 応援. It's also just the on'yomi readings you learned.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. 応援 is a word you've seen before, so if you know that this word will be easier.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

You love <vocabulary>to carry</vocabulary> things, especially <reading>cats</reading> (かつ). You hoist them up onto your shoulders and carry them all around town.

The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

The kanji stands by itself with a particle, meaning that this uses the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. Here's a mnemonic to help you:

You know a person that starts every other sentence by saying "<vocabulary>Furthermore</vocabulary>," and that's... <reading>Sarah</reading> (さら). Really feel yourself getting annoyed with this Sarah for starting every other sentence with "Furthermore, ...!"

Just note that 更に is often written in kana, as さらに, especially in casual writing!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading is the vocab words 朝 and 寝坊 put together into one. So long as you know them separately you should know them together too!

This is when you're burning something. To remember this meaning, you have to remember the も part. So, just think of your friend <reading>Mo</reading>e (も), and how you're going to burn him... uh... just a little bit.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

The reading is the same as the kanji, so you're good to go here. It may be a <vocabulary>narrow</vocabulary> way of thinking about this kanji, but it will help you out the most.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Everyone's here <vocabulary>to celebrate</vocabulary>, and all you can say is "<reading>Eek, wha</reading>...!?" (いわ). All your friends and family have come to celebrate your birthday, but you had no idea. Still confused and processing the situation, you keep saying, "Eek... what?" The surprise was a complete success!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

If you're going to get stabbed, don't get stabbed <reading>two</reading> (つ) times. You can remember that this is the "two time stab" stab because it has a hole that's big. The hole is big because you got stabbed twice.

"That's <reading>coo' だ</reading>," you like to say in response to <vocabulary>pipe</vocabulary>s. You've never seen pipes before, which makes them pretty cool to you. You've been using an outhouse your whole life, so pipes are pretty neat.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You want <vocabulary>to build something</vocabulary> called a <reading>key zoo</reading> (きず). Which is a zoo for keys instead of animals. So it's a bunch of keys in cages, basically. Hmm, how artsy of you... Hopefully people get it. Isn't it a bit avant-garde <vocabulary>to construct something</vocabulary> like a key zoo?
The reading is the readings of 置く and 場 put together.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you go <vocabulary>to undress</vocabulary> your goal is to become <reading>nu</reading>de (ぬ).
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

You only like <vocabulary>to touch</vocabulary> things that are <reading>sour</reading> (さわ). Lemons, limes, grapefruits, you name it. There's something about sour things that just makes you want to touch them.

A reporter asks for your conversation <vocabulary>to be placed on</vocabulary> record, to which you respond "<reading>NO</reading> (の)!" Koichi doesn't want everyone to know that he didn’t notice a cactus had been placed on his seat until…
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

I have <vocabulary>to mention</vocabulary> this thing... "<reading>NO</reading>," (の) you quickly respond. I don't want you mentioning that here and now.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading comes from 過ぎる. Know that and you know <vocabulary>too much</vocabulary>. Dial it down to get 過ぎ.

You need <vocabulary>to measure</vocabulary> the quantity of something, but don't have a scale or anything. Luckily, you are quite the <reading>hacker</reading> (はか) and hack together a scale using only rubber bands and beans.
This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this already!
This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
